Derek James wrote:

>--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
>  
>
>>Do you need the ID for your XSLT? 
>>    
>>
>Yes.  The XSL writes the connection weight out along the path of the 
>connection, which has to have an id, so to associate the weight text, 
>there needs to a unique identifier associated with the connection.  
>
>  
>
>>I think the same applies to the 
>>recurrent flag.
>>    
>>
>
>The XSL draws recurrent connections in red and forward ones in black, 
>which is useful for visualization.  Any XSL style sheet is not going 
>to be smart enough to determine whether a connection is recurrent or 
>not (which, as has been pointed out, can be very complicated logic).
>  
>
Ok, understood. So would you say that both the id and the 'recurrent' 
flag can be considered optional? Sorry to seem pedantic on this one but 
I want to be 100% sure we're all undestanding each other.

>It is probably best to determine whether or not a given connection is 
>recurrent or not, then explicitly store that information in the XML.  
>This will be necessary for anyone either drawing (if you want to 
>render that information visually) the network or trying to reproduce 
>its functionality.  
>  
>
Agreed. Right now my own code doesn't detect recurrency at all, so if I 
have to output a flag then I'll just set it to false and get all black 
connections. Not a problem.

>In our framework, when a connection is designated "recurrent", all it 
>really means, from an implementation standpoint, is that the output 
>from the previous timestep is stored and re-input.
>
ok. I'm beginning to realise that everyone's network code may not 
function quite as I had thought. In SharpNEAT (my pet project) ALL of  
the neurons store their output value, this then is the basis of 
calculating the activation input and output for the next time step. 
Right now I actually loop through each of the neurons once per time 
slice in the order they appear in the genome, calculating the new output 
values for each neuron and storing it in a seperate variable on the 
neuron. A second loop then switches all of the neurons over to their 
newly calculated output value ready for the next time step.  This 
technique is distinct from a routine that actually traverses the 
network, calculating output values as it goes - which I guess would 
require a recurrency flag to prevent the traversal from following the 
loop indefinitely.  Is this network traversal what others are doing?    
Anyway, the point being that the technique I use doesn't know and 
doesn't need to know about recurrency, at least not during a simulation, 
hence my confusion about the recurrency flag up until now :)

>  And because it is 
>not clear whether or not some neurons should be designated recurrent, 
>it is best to explicitly include that information with the XML.  
>
If the recuurency flag is an integral part of the network's operation 
then yes I agree.

Regards,

Colin.
